articles.headline: Patchwork Pension Plan Adds to Greek Debt Woes
articles.snippet: Greece’s retirement plan, which lets 14 percent of its work force retire early, has become divisive in Europe.
articles.abstract: Greece’s retirement plan, which lets 14 percent of its work force retire early, has become divisive in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Vasia Veremi may be only 28, but as a hairdresser in Athens, she is keenly aware that, under a current law that treats her job as hazardous to her health, she has the right to retire with a full pension at age 50.

articles.headline: Dealing With Fraud by Denial
articles.snippet: Investors in CMKM Diamonds are suing the S.E.C. for $3.87 trillion for knowing about a fraud at the tiny firm but not stopping it.
articles.abstract: Investors in CMKM Diamonds are suing the S.E.C. for $3.87 trillion for knowing about a fraud at the tiny firm but not stopping it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Years after Charles Ponzi was imprisoned for a fraud that cost victims millions of dollars in 1920, the state of Massachusetts determined it had recovered all the assets it could, and began to distribute them to victims, who stood to receive less than 30 cents for each dollar they invested.

articles.headline: To Take on Botox, Rival Tries Rebate
articles.snippet: Medicis has started a new marketing campaign that pits its wrinkle-smoother, Dysport, directly against Botox. It makes bioethicists squirm.
articles.abstract: Medicis has started a new marketing campaign that pits its wrinkle-smoother, Dysport, directly against Botox. It makes bioethicists squirm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Allergan and Medicis Pharmaceutical are the Coke and Pepsi of vanity medicine.

articles.headline: Report Details How Lehman Hid Its Woes
articles.snippet: The bank used accounting gimmicks to hide its weakness in the months before its bankruptcy, a report says.
articles.abstract: The bank used accounting gimmicks to hide its weakness in the months before its bankruptcy, a report says.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the Wall Street equivalent of a coroner’s report — a 2,200-page document that lays out, in new and startling detail, how Lehman Brothers used accounting sleight of hand to conceal the bad investments that led to its undoing.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Rapid Rise in Seed Prices Draws U.S. Scrutiny
articles.snippet: A Justice Department antitrust investigation of the seed industry is apparently focused on Monsanto.
articles.abstract: A Justice Department antitrust investigation of the seed industry is apparently focused on Monsanto.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the depths of the economic crisis last year, the prices for many goods held steady or even dropped. But on American farms, the picture was far different, as farmers watched the price they paid for seeds skyrocket. Corn seed prices rose 32 percent; soybean seeds were up 24 percent.

articles.headline: Lexus, a Toyota Brand, Avoids Taint From Recalls
articles.snippet: The brand’s sales and reputation have held up, analysts say, because Lexus has not been included in Toyota’s most serious recalls.
articles.abstract: The brand’s sales and reputation have held up, analysts say, because Lexus has not been included in Toyota’s most serious recalls.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been a rough few months for Toyota because of its three big safety recalls. But the automaker’s luxury division, Lexus, appears to have avoided much of the fallout.

articles.headline: Instant Ads Set the Pace on the Web
articles.snippet: Companies like Google, Yahoo and Microsoft let advertisers buy ads in the milliseconds between the time someone enters a site’s Web address and the moment the page appears.
articles.abstract: Companies like Google, Yahoo and Microsoft let advertisers buy ads in the milliseconds between the time someone enters a site’s Web address and the moment the page appears.
articles.lead_paragraph: Time is now on the side of online advertisers.

articles.headline: Obama Social Secretary Ran Into Sharp Elbows
articles.snippet: The rise and fall of Desirée Rogers, the White House social secretary, is in some ways a familiar Washington tale.
articles.abstract: The rise and fall of Desirée Rogers, the White House social secretary, is in some ways a familiar Washington tale.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Long before the State Dinner party crashers and the tension with her White House colleagues and the strain in her relationship with the first lady, Desirée Rogers began to understand she was in trouble when David Axelrod summoned her to his office last spring to scold her.

articles.headline: Cost of Stadium Reveals Tensions in South Africa
articles.snippet: Even as a $137 million stadium to be used for four World Cup games is rising, poverty remains prevalent nearby.
articles.abstract: Even as a $137 million stadium to be used for four World Cup games is rising, poverty remains prevalent nearby.
articles.lead_paragraph: NELSPRUIT, South Africa — Come June, soccer’s World Cup will be hosted by South Africa. Though only 4 of the 64 games are to be played here in Nelspruit, a $137 million stadium was built for the occasion. The arena’s 18 supporting pylons reach skyward in the shape of orange giraffes. At nightfall, their eyeballs blink with flashes of bewitching light.
